name: propylene production, from propane dehydrogenation | butene, mixed | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/29166/documentation

This process represents the production of 1 kg of propylene from propane dehydrogenation.;The dehydrogenation of light alkanes (i.e., propane and butane) attracted significant attention for the selective large-scale production of light olefins. During the dehydrogenation reaction, two carbon-hydrogen bonds break leading to the production of hydrogen, as valuable byproduct, and the formation of a carbon-carbon double bond. The economic viability of the selectrive production of olefins via dehydrogenation is influenced by the market price of the feedstock, i.e., alkanes, and the the valuable products, i.e., olefins. Notably, the propane dehydrogenation technology allows the on-purpose production of propylene (as the main reference product) and thus, shifting from its conventional production as a byproduct in steam crackers.;There are several proceseses, for dehydrogenation, explored commercially. This dataset describes the Oleflex process. The processes mainly distinguish in their catalyst use and regeneration. Propane dehydrogenation processes are highly selective, overall yields of propylene production of up to 90 % are claimed.;In the United States, 50% of propylene are produced by refineries, 35% by steam cracking, 13% by propane dehydrogenation and the remaining 2% by other technologies.;This dataset is extrapolated from the Chinese dataset.;References:;Eisele P.,Killpack R. (2011): Propene, Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemisty, Wiley-VCH.;Lv, L.; Song, G.; Zhao, X.; Chen, J. (2021): Environmental Burdens of China’s Propylene manufacturing: Comparative life-cycle assessment and scenario analysis, Science of the Total Environment, 799, 149451.;Nawaz, Z. (2015). Light alkane dehydrogenation to light olefin technologies: a comprehensive review. Reviews in chemical engineering, 31(5), 413-436.

From the reception of propane at the factory gate.

The activity ends with propylene being ready for further processing or transportation at the production site gate. Infrastructure is included.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Based on a scientific publication. The technology is not expected to change over time.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Inventory extrapolated to the US geography based on a Chinese production plant.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: There are several proceseses explored commercially, this dataset describes the Oleflex process. The processes are distinguished mainly based on their catalyst use and regeneration. Propane dehydrogenation processes are highly selective, overall yields of propylene from propane up to 90 % are claimed.;The propane feed is admitted to a moving-bed catalytic reactor. In a continuous process, the dehydrogenation catalyst circulates through the reaction vessel before passing to a separate regeneration vessel where coke is removed from the surface of the catalyst by combustion in air. The regenerated catalyst is returned to the first reactor.;Propene is recovered by conventional deethanizer – depropanizer splitting.;An overall selectivity for propene of 89 – 91% is claimed.;The chemical reaction of the reaction is:;C3H8 --> C3H6 + H2;The reaction is catalysed by a platinum-based catalyst, due to lack of data the catalyst was neglected.;References:;Eisele P.,Killpack R. (2011): Propene, Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemisty, Wiley-VCH.;Lv, L.; Song, G.; Zhao, X.; Chen, J. (2021): Environmental Burdens of China’s Propylene manufacturing: Comparative life-cycle assessment and scenario analysis, Science of the Total Environment, 799, 149451.

exchanges.description:
Valuable byproduct from the dehydrogenation of propane (i.e., C3H8 --> C3H6 + H2)
Reference:
Lv, L.; Song, G.; Zhao, X.; Chen, J. (2021): Environmental Burdens of China’s Propylene manufacturing: Comparative life-cycle assessment and scenario analysis, Science of the Total Environment, 799, 149451.

exchanges.description:
Reference:
Lv, L.; Song, G.; Zhao, X.; Chen, J. (2021): Environmental Burdens of China’s Propylene manufacturing: Comparative life-cycle assessment and scenario analysis, Science of the Total Environment, 799, 149451.

Calculated based on literature data published by the industry. For this activity, no information was readily available concerning infrastructure and land-use. Therefore, the infrastructure is estimated based on data from two chemical factories, the BASF site of Ludwigshafen and the chemical factory in Gendorf (which are both located in Germany), which produce a wide range of chemical substances. Based on this data, the following assumptions are made: the built area amounts to about 4.2 ha, the plant has an average output of 50'000 t/a and a lifespan of fifty years. The estimated infrastructure amount is therefore 4.00 E-10 units per kg of produced chemical.
This amount is scaled by the amount of chemicals produced.

References:
Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.
Gendorf (2000) Umwelterklärung 2000, Werk Gendorf. Werk Gendorf, Burgkirchen.

Fuel gas input used for heating. The original source did not specify the nature of the fuel gas, and thus, natural gas was used in this dataset. The amount in the source in kg was divided by the density of natural gas at standard conditions, 0.735 kg/m3.
Reference:
Lv, L.; Song, G.; Zhao, X.; Chen, J. (2021): Environmental Burdens of China’s Propylene manufacturing: Comparative life-cycle assessment and scenario analysis, Science of the Total Environment, 799, 149451.

Calculated value. The original source provided a value of 2.86 kg of steam per kg of propylene produced via propane dehydrogenation. The given value was convereted to energy (based on 2.75 MJ per kg heating value) since steam does not participate actively in the reaction scheme.
Reference:
Lv, L.; Song, G.; Zhao, X.; Chen, J. (2021): Environmental Burdens of China’s Propylene manufacturing: Comparative life-cycle assessment and scenario analysis, Science of the Total Environment, 799, 149451.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. The input of oxygen is introduced to account for oxygen used in fuel combustion to CO2. This is done by calculating the molecular share of oxygen (molar weight of O2 31.998 g/mol) in carbon dioxide (molecular weight 44.01 g/mol).
